nodes.text: Increasing sleep among the urban poor will improve economic outcomes (productivity, cognition, well-being, and decision making).
Urban poor adults in Chennai are severely sleep-deprived compared to expert recommendations and appear to have low sleep quality.
We measured sleep objectively using wrist actigraphy and implemented a randomized controlled trial (RCT) with rich outcome measurement.
Baseline evidence (actigraphy): average night sleep ≈5.5 hours, time in bed ≈8 hours, sleep efficiency ≈70%, ≈31 awakenings per night; self-reports overestimate sleep.

RCT interventions: two night-sleep bundles (devices + encouragement; devices + financial incentives) and a cross-randomized workplace half-hour nap opportunity; participants worked a month-long paid data-entry job with detailed outcome collection.

Night-sleep interventions increased nighttime sleep by 27 minutes on average (larger for incentives), driven entirely by increased time in bed (~38 minutes) with no significant change in sleep efficiency.
The nap intervention increased daytime (workplace) sleep by about 14 minutes on average, with higher measured nap sleep efficiency and fewer awakenings during naps in the office environment.

Pooled night-sleep increases had no detectable positive effects on overall index, cognition, productivity, decision making, preferences, or well-being, and they reduced labor supply by about nine minutes per day leading to small decreases in earnings.

Naps increased the overall summary index by 0.12 standard deviations and yielded significant improvements in productivity, psychological well-being, lab measures of cognition and attention at work, while reducing work time during the nap period.
Surveyed experts (sleep science and economics) predicted sizable economic benefits (median predicted ~7% increase in output for +30 minutes night sleep), predictions that the RCT results rejected.

Low sleep efficiency in this population implies high opportunity costs: increasing one minute of actual sleep required substantially more (empirically ≈1.4) minutes in bed, limiting available time for work/leisure.

Key outcomes and measurements: daily actigraphy (night and nap sleep metrics), precise labor-supply and productivity from the data-entry platform, earnings, lab cognitive tasks (PVT, memory, inhibitory control), well-being surveys, and experimental measures of preferences and savings.

Possible explanations for null nighttime-sleep benefits include (a) marginal, policy-relevant increases differ from severe lab-induced deprivation experiments; (b) poor sleep quality (low efficiency, frequent awakenings) reduces marginal returns; and (c) timing of sleep matters so naps and night sleep are not perfect substitutes.

Conclusion and policy-relevant claim: In this urban poor Chennai setting, increasing nighttime sleep via modest interventions yields low short-run economic returns and notable opportunity costs, while workplace naps produce measurable benefits; policymakers should not uncritically extrapolate lab results or expert priors and should consider preserving or enabling naps in workplaces.

Limitations: three-week treatment window for many outcomes, generalizability concerns beyond the specific sample and job context, limited ability to disentangle timing versus quality effects, and possible longer-term health effects not captured.
